monogr.title: The golden booke of the leaden goddes : Wherein is described the vayne imaginations of heathe [n] pagans, and counterfaict Christians: wyth a description of their seueral tables, what ech of their pictures signified. By Stephan Batman, student in diuinitie
monogr.author: Batman, Stephen

div.head: E. L. in the Authors Commendation.

lg.l: HE merites Fame (I say) that taketh payne,
Not for himselfe, but for his natiue Soyle:
Where one alone the profite shall not gayne,
But all may reape the sweete, of his sower toyle.
By all mens doome, that Man must needes haue prayse,
Who for behoofe of others, spendes his dayes.
Then since that all, by one, shall profite get,
What she disdaynes the trauaylle of this wight?
Not one: vnlesse such Curres as stil do set
Themselues to byte at those, who bring to light
The slye deceiptes of their vngracious Crewe,
Who vertuous men to hurt do still pursue.
Braue golden workes may Iewels called bee,
That fine been formde with shape of straunge deuise:
Such Iewels then, let not to viewe and see
Mo times then once, yea, more then twise or thryse:
For why? the rarenesse of this piece is such.
To view it styll, you cannot do too much.
For proofe, lo here that Iewell rare in sight,
This Booke beholde, that Leaden Gods contayne:
And how a Bar, like glittring Gold most bright,
Those glosinge Gods depaintes in colours playne:
That euery man, which doth his Booke beholde,
For guerdon will geeue it, the name of Golde.
Certes, such a worke in English neuer was
As this (though small) which doth vayne thinges bewraye:
What then needes hee, that made the same once passe,
On Romish Curres, what they do barke or say:
No let them gnarle, and do the worst they can,
The Worke is good, the proofe shal prayse the Man.
